content.rendered:
Today we get a full dose of Catalan-ness with work from designers in Barcelona for clients in Barcelona.

Cocolia by Cocolia

When it feels like you are burdened by a small budget look no further for hope than the business cards of Cocolia, a graphic design duo in Barcelona, who silkscreened their cards in one color and then customized the back of each of them in a unique spray painted pattern that is like a 1980s pastel-colored party. The spray dots, lines, and squiggles aren’t totally gratuitous either: if you go to their website your cursor will transform into all of them and you can also see furniture spray painted with the same motifs. See full project.

Maio by TwoPoints.Net

This flexible identity system by TwoPoints.Net for architecture firm Maio is deployed on three different rolls of tape, all featuring patterns of the logo and the company’s information so that any piece of paper can be turned into a letterhead, business card, or postcard. (I wish we could see actual photos on TwoPoints.net’s case study instead of renderings). The color combination is charming and the abstract patterns are attractive. See full project.

Super3 by Diestro

This is one where we might have to agree to disagree. Launched in 2009, Super3 is a Spanish public television channel for kids and teenagers broadcast in Catalan. A couple of years ago, motion graphics shop Diestro was tasked with bringing the identity to 3D awesomeness. As much as this is likely not my (or most’s) style, the result is as energetic as an 8-year-old jumping on his or her bed right before bedtime. (Conversely, it can also be annoying). This is unapologetically 3D-ish with the logo doing every possible visual summersault to get attention. And it works. See full project.
